title: Do soldiers take items from dead soldiers? - Quora

response.answer_text: In all recorded history of armies, soldiers have helped themselves to the valuables of dead soldiers, friend or foe. In my WW 2 experience, tankers would claim that 4 or 5 infantry would be searching a dead enemy before he hit the ground! I along with many others carried a long blade knife, called a “ pocket splitter” for obvious reasons. I have seen a GI cutting a finger off an enemy casualty to get a ring. The notion that an ordinary foot soldier should be searched for ,or possess, papers of tactical or strategic value is foolish and nonsensical. If weapons were taken, it was for a souvenir usually, although enemy pistols…particularly a P 38 or Luger…might be carried both as a souvenir and as a personal weapon. Also , they had monetary value and were a desirable buy by rear echelon troops. At one encounter , after shooting a grenade out of the hand of a Hauptmann ( Battalion Commander) I captured his staff of 28 by throwing White Phosphorus grenades into their office in the cellar of the town Post Office, (which subsequently burned to the ground). I then distributed their numerous pistols to my squad members. Most were subsequently sold. Those of my buddies whom had been captured told me later that German soldiers stripped them of their valuables and did the same looting of jewelry, cash or other valuables from dead or captured troops. sidelight….a few days after we invaded Southern France, my squad was returned to clean out what had been a German Army training area . After blowing a safe and cleaning out the cash register in their PX, we were the possessors of about $20,000 in Francs, divided amongst the 12 of us. When many of us had been in Africa earlier, the Germans , in captured France, had availed themselves of their printing presses to run off huge amounts of Francs. Thus , in Africa Francs were valueless and we therefore assumed the same was true here. Soooo….what do you do with worthless paper? Toss them to the kids as you ride through a liberated town or play millionaire and light cigarettes with it. Since toilet paper is always in short supply for troops on the move, that was a very common use. This event was subsequently written up in the Stars and Stripes army newspaper. The result was a visit by army investigators to recover any remaining funds. Too late! It had been shitted away……

You take what you need, whether it’s from your own dead soldiers or from the enemy’s. If you see a dead body on the battlefield (and if there is no fighting going on), you usually want to make a little inspection. You want to know who this guy is and the cause of his death. If it’s one of your own, you might want to recover the body. If you find an ID, dog tags, maps or documents, you take them and hand them over to your superior at the end of your mission. The same goes for personal belongings like photos, letters, jewelry and money. Weapons, ammunition and other combat gear have to be taken or destroyed. You don’t want the enemy or anyone else to get their hands on it. In case you can’t carry all the stuff and you are unable to properly destroy it (because the noise would draw the enemy's attention, for example), try to hide it a good distance away from the body. Of course, if your own weapon is damaged or you are low on ammo you help yourself. During the Kosovo War I took an AK-47 from a dead Serb and it served me well until the end of the war. All the things that might help you to accomplish your mission not only can, but should be taken! And all things that drag you down must be left behind. These rules are quite simple and are applicable for the treatment of dead soldiers from both sides. When it comes to certain items there seems to be a grey zone: can I take food from the enemy? What’s with cigarettes? Is a watch a military item or a personal belonging? These questions are for ethics classes in law school. In reality, when you are hungry or haven’t had a smoke for several weeks, you won’t hesitate to take it. Friend or foe - the dead don’t need that stuff anymore.

Do soldiers take items from dead soldiers? It's useful, even important, to collect weapons and ammunition, equipment and supplies, from fallen comrades.  It makes the survivors more effective, and keeps the items from being used against the survivors.  Similarly, removing such items from enemy casualties is important, too, if only to destroy the equipment. Robbing the dead is different.  The dead comrades' personal belongings can be sent to their next of kin, as keepsakes and as evidence that the dead body was treated with respect.  Robbing a dead enemy of personal belongings or desirable personal equipment is suicidal, if there is any risk that the thief will fall into enemy hands.  Combat troops often react very emotionally and violently if they find that a prisoner has robbed the captors' fallen comrades.  Historically, being captured with good enemy boots, foul weather clothing, items with enemy soldiers' names, or multiple rings/watches/wallets often led to instant retaliation. Most armies have rules that enemy casualties' belongings should be preserved for their intelligence value, and most armies have regulations that items of value that are defined as war booty are to be considered as government property. And stealing from enemy dead is a war crime, often also against regulations.Customary IHL (index) Practice Relating to Rule 49. War BootyPractice Relating to Rule 113. Treatment of the Dead  .

Of course they do, did you never see how many watches they wore from killed enemies?  ""War lootingThe sacking and looting of Mechelen by the Spanish troops led by the Duke of Alba, 2 October 1572 practice through Looting by a victorious army during war has been common out recorded history.  For foot soldiers, it was viewed as a way to supple-ment their often meagre income and was part of the celebration of victory.  On hi-gher levels, the proud exhibition of loot was an integral part of the typical Roman triumph, and Genghis Khan was not unusual in proclaiming that the greatest happiness was "to vanquish your enemies... to rob them of their wealth..."In warfare in ancient times, the spoils of war included the defeated populations, which were often enslaved, and the women and children, who were often absorbed into the victorious country's population.  In other pre-modern societies, objects made of precious metals were the preferred target of war looting, largely because of their easy portability.  In many cases looting was an opportunity to obtain treasures that otherwise would not have been obtainable.  Since the 18th century, works of art have increasingly become a popular target.  In the 1930s and even more so during World War II, Nazi Germany engaged in large scale and organized looting of art and property.  Looting, combined with poor military discipline, has occasionally been an army's downfall.  In other cases, for example the Wahhabi sack of Karbala, loot has financed further victories.  Not all looters in wartime are conquerors; the looting of Vistula Land by its retreating defenders in 1915  was among the factors sapping the loyalty of Poland in World War I.  Local civilians can also take advantage of a break-down of authority to loot public and private property, such as took place at the National Museum of Iraq in the course of the Iraq War in 2003.  The novel War and Peace describes widespread looting by Moscow's citizens before Napoleon's troops enter the town, and looting by French troops elsewhere." Looting

First, if you see a dead body (probably enemy since the US military makes every effort of recovering our own), the first thing for consideration is if the body is boobytrapped, in places like Iraq & Afghanistan bomb-makers are always looking for places to hide their handiwork. Second consideration is does this “person” have anything that is noteworthy regarding military intelligence or weapons? If so, the Military Police will recover it. There is nothing on that dead body worth loosing your career or freedom. Taking anything from a dead body is a violation of US Regulations and is punishable by a General Courtmartial. A war zone is nothing like Hollywood portrays it. Today's US Soldier goes to war with everything they need, plus while in Iraq or Afghanistan, they receive more resupply items like boots and uniforms, ammo, etc. If a weapon isn't working as it should, it can either be replaced or repaired in theater. If you smoke, you have several options, have someone back home mail them to you, buy them at the Shoppette on the FOB or one nearby, get one from a battle-buddy, or quit! Buying cigarettes from locals is dangerous because they might be laced with something that could ruin your day or your life. If it was food, would you eat anything that came off a dead body?

It’s been done throughout history probably since the caveman days. My time I can honestly say I never saw it in Iraq or Afghanistan. Did happen? Probably but what do you really need to take of a dead enemy combatant? Except for intel or something that could be used for intel purposes that’s about it. We had everything we needed plus more. If we wanted war trophies we could get that thru legit sources over there. Both my grandfathers served in WWII and they never spoke about. It was after one of my grandfathers passed did we find out more. We were cleaning out his closets and came upon a old wood box with his name rank and unit stenciled on it. It was filled with his war memorabilia pictures of him and his buddies in Germany letters to my grandma one letter in German which could have been a document and letters from him to his army buddies even after the war. His ribbons and metals and award citations after reading them I realized why he never spoke about the war he was right in the middle of shit in France and Germany. Found a Nazi armband which looked like it had some dark stains in the white “ Now yellowed from age “ it probably came of a dead Nazi a dagger complete with eagle and swastika which had some German writing on the blade a lugar pistol and assorted money from France and Germany. I kept all his pictures and letters and donated the Nazi Germany items to my grandfathers hometown museum in Ohio that had a feature of the men in town that fought in the pacific and Europe.

One of my uncles served in WW2 on the western front. When I’d visit my cousins as kids, sometimes they’d go into the attic and we’d look at the souvenirs he brought home. A knife, a couple belt buckles, some decorations, and some objects we had no idea what they were. What particularly fascinated us was a photo album that appears to be of a German family from before the war. Pictures of them having a picnic, playing by a lake, riding bicycles. Was the former owner one of the boys pictured within? The father? No idea. As a kid in the 1960s, you got your idea of German soldiers from TV shows like “Combat!” so seeing this side of a German soldier was unknown to us. He also had about a half dozen passport-like documents that had pictures of a German soldier within and writing in German. Our uncle refused to talk about the war. Well, refused to talk about battle anyway. We never knew for sure if he took these items from Germans that he captured or had killed or found. Our childhood imaginations ran wild and we concluded that these were from German soldiers he killed - why else would he have kept them? I pondered whether some of these (the photo album and the passports) should be returned to the families if possible, but after my uncle died, they passed into the hands of one of my cousins who doesn’t want to part with them.

It probably would’ve been cool to get my hands on a Walther or a painted Stahlhelm or a Rebel Bowie knife or something interesting and historically significant like that, depending on the era of American soldier. But that seems to only have been generally accepted when fighting a conventional war against fat rich equals.   I don’t know about other people, but the only thing that our “people under confinement” or enemy dead were likely to have on them would be not-enough-afghani (local money) to buy a rug, the dirtiest miswak, and the nastiest chew, which apparently wasn’t even mostly tabacco. A good raid meant a fat cache of weapons or IED material or computers or whatnot that might’ve had intelligence potential, but in Afghanistan in 2006–2008, there were also instances where it was just some kid who looked old enough to be a killer when he got nabbed, but instead just lived in a house that was marked as Taliban by his asshole neighbor who had a vendetta against his family someway or another.   We had so many laws in place against war trophies, and our mail was screened pretty thoroughly. So much in fact that mailroom douchebags stole some of my coolest legally purchased gifts to be sent home. It’s a little late in the game if you’re into collecting ears or fingers of what have you, but I remember a story where some soldiers were charged with exactly that. US soldiers 'killed Afghan civilians for sport and collected fingers as trophies'

Yes, but only what they need. Contrary to usual perception, soldiers do not loot the dead for their personal items, money or other valuables. They loot the dead for ammunition, weapons, explosives, food and gear. Looting the dead for their valuables is considered an utterly disgraceful act - especially if the dead is one of your own. But on the other hand, taking ammunition, weapons, gear, rations and other utilitarian objects is not considered grave robbery but rather collecting what you need. In case of your own, it is also considered as recovering the items. Marauding (= looting and robbing the enemy dead and/or civilian targets for profit) is a war crime and a sure-fire way for enemy retaliations and revenge. If a soldier is caught possessing personal belongings of an enemy soldier, he is VERY likely to get shot by the angry comrades of the fallen soldier.

The Yom Kippur war caught the IDF with its pants down. There was a lack of many personal items. A common military expression was "equipment augmentation" (literal translation), a euphemism for stealing gear. On my battalion's advance up the Golan Heights we encountered a position which had been overrun by the Syrians. Nobody was there. I can't remember what kind of unit and whether there were any bodies there. A senior NCO was caught looting a few jackets. He probably wasn't issued with one. Whatever. He was kicked out so fast I have no idea what happened to him . …. Two or three weeks after the outbreak of the war we were pulled out of the front line and sent to reorganize and recuperate in the base of one of the battalions of 188 Tank Brigade which had been decimated in the awfull first day of the war. We were sure nobody was coming back . So we broke into several lockers and helped ourselves to all kinds of stuff. Imagine the red faces when the survivors began drifting back.

I have taken their ammo and knife and or weapon when needed. I never took anything personal except for items that I would send back to their families. Anything I could use in combat was fair game. Most combat men did not carry their wallets or anything like that but my best friend did have a ring and watch which I removed to send back home. Their rucksack may contain food or clothes that could be used. Please remember they were our brothers and they would want us to use what we could. I never served with women soldiers because in my day they weren't in combat in the field, but the same would apply, if useable then it was OK. The enemy the only thing I took would be their rank insignia, flag, and ID Tags and explode any weapons and ammo that could be used against us, we mostly burned the bodies.

In regular basic training I went into the troop sgts office for some reason in 1999. I noticed a large framed set of pictures, main one was the Sgt as a younger tank crewman on Challenger in 1991 in the Gulf war. 1st image was him and a smashed T55 and a few Iraqi dead lying around. One Iraqi wore a red and white shamagh scarf. 2nd and 3rd images were from further out engaging the T55 and it subsequently on fire. In a small box a scrap of red and white shamagh was also attached. So I'd presume this was souvenir-ed at the time. By my deployment to Kuwait and Iraq in 2003 a few years later souvenirs were discouraged, but I retrieved a few harmless items and a lot of dusty tatty kit.

Needless to say you police the battlefield, collecting weapons, documents, and unfortunately even personal journals, (since you have no idea what they say) flags or banners if any, but leave clothing, pictures behind. That’s the way it worked in my battalion. Captured automatic weapons had to be turned in to S-2 . You could not keep an AK-47 but pistols, knives and SKS (semi-automatic) was yours to take home if you liked. However when I began my tour in 1969, captured SKS were slim pickings. Nonetheless some Marines did take belt buckles or cut off piece of uniform, but most wanted nothing to do with war souvenirs

Do soldiers take items from dead soldiers?  When I was a child, I discovered a German bayonet in a metal chest in my grandfather’s shed. My grandfather had served in World War I and had brought the bayonet back. I never asked him how he came by it. Did he find it in a trench? Did someone give it to him as a souvenir? Did he take it from a dead soldier? I wrote about my discovery and more recent musings on it here: My Grandfather's Shed and the Great War by Michael Durcan on Eclectic Anecdotes.

Sure. Taking military items (firearms, ammunition, grenades, etc.) is done to keep enemy soldiers or civilians from obtaining them. Depending on the rules in effect, these may be turned over to commanders to be destroyed or in some cases kept as war trophies. Taking things that have intelligence value (maps, radios, etc) is of course done as well. Taking personal effects of enemy dead is generally looked down upon and is also generally considered a war crime.

They do. My grandfather fought in the pacific with the 2nd marine division. Took part in 3 separate invasions: Tarawa, Okinawa and Saipan. I don’t know where or when he got these items, but at some point he did snag a Japanese Arisaka rifle with chrysanthemum(16 pedal flower, a symbol of the Japanese emperor) still on it, from the battlefield.  (not the actual rifle my grandfather took, but you can see the flower intact on this rifle) The chrysanthemum was scratched off of many of the rifles by Japanese soldiers after the formal surrender to try to save face. I’m also told he did take a blood soaked wallet that had war time Japanese currency as well as a picture of the poor guys wife, but my mother has this hidden away.

I did not serve in combat but I spoke to many soldiers who did. The impression I got was that many soldiers felt a closer kinship with the enemy soldiers than with civilians who had never served. In basic training we were told that it was illegal to take personal possessions from enemy casualties and it was stupid to take anything else because of the high risk that it had been booby-trapped.

Sure. Why wouldn't you? You need ammo, water, food, first aid supplies, maybe even their weapon. Maybe his boot size are the same as yours and yours are worn out, same thing with packs, helmets, comms, whatever. Personal items, most US soldiers have more decency than that. Dead enemy soldiers, that's a good way to end up dead or severely wounded. Boobytrapped soldiers are nothing new.

Yes. Here are dead federal soldiers at Gettysburg. Notice how their shoes are missing? Just a basic example. Here much needed footwear was taken and used by the foot sore Confederate soldiers. It has been a common practice since the first 2 men went to war against one another. I bet the first victor took the first loser's loincloth. Just sayin.

You take what you need in some circumstances. Extra magazines, grenades , other pieces of gear. ( you commrades) Dead enemies get searched for anything of intel value. Cell phones in my day. Hand over cell phones from dead enemy combatants to intel geeks, and they damn near wet themselves in excitement. Other papers pass ports ect also get handed over. Weapons: depends on situation. After the fight they get collected up and are either destroyed, or issued to our allies in the local military.

About a year in to my service I saw a private photo of a dozen or so hands strung up on a fence. There was no context so I couldn’t discern the truth of the matter. I later heard rumours that some factions of the Angola war were encouraged to bring the severed hands of enemies for a bounty. It seems that some enterprising types were cutting hands off people who were not combatants - guess how that ended.

Sometimes. When I was a 1SG my NCOs and I had an informal rule that if you were killed the surviving would split up your gear. We would yell “dibs” at the meeting before someone went on mission on what we wanted. It was more of Comradery thing then anything else. In real life you take what you need, collect the rest for safe keeping and to be returned to the family, leave nothing that the enemy can use. You don’t leave anyone behind.

By n large, I agree w most commentary. However,Earlier wars —. Yes. The enemy’s medics were prime looting. By and large, looting medics was for money. Just minor sidebar, prior to going over seas and If we’d get a 48 hr+ liberty, we would give blood to blood banks for money. Amazing what a few dollars would get you in Tijuana . Regarding survival needs, taking of usable munitions n stuff was never considered looting. That said, the motivation was money and souvenirs. However — again, seen marines do and get some real crazy stuff. We did it discreetly , an unspoken, understanding was made. And the higher ups always supported the old tenant Of gathering intelligence.

Yes, I think they are allowed to do that. Although oftentimes soldiers would take something that I, for example, wouldn't. Some things aren’t to take. I would call that looting. But things like left gear and other military stuff is okay. Your question reminded me of the story, when my Russian uncle took a beautiful, multi-volume pack of art books with the most beautiful prints - all kinds of art, from a bombed-out house in Dusseldorf. I only wonder how that heavy stack got transported back with him. Those books today, are priceless. They decorate my library. They have signatures. Anyway, that’s what I think on this matter. By the way, take a look at this antique gear.
Of course. Extra ammunition, food, maps, water, etc. It would be good to leave these things behind.On the other hand, if you're asking about souvenirs, the answer is still yes.
Russians fight for the Mother land, British fight for the King or Queen, Germans fight for the Father land, but Americans fight for souvenirs.
